description: Brian Cullinan Here is my beef with big tech companies and my data:  1. Facebook makes it impossible to download every picture of me or tagged with me.  2. If I get a call from a recruiter I met on LinkedIn, the caller ID shows up as unknown.  3. Google collects tons of data from me, but doesn’t make it useful to me.  A famous data scientist recently told me that it doesn’t matter if you collect all the data in the world, what matters are the actions you take based on that data.  Productivity is an output we have been trying to measure more accurately for centuries.  If we could accurately count the number of compliments given in an office, would that show a correlation with productivity?

comments.content: Marilyn J Bartlett

Well I don't think anyone has ever said that the services were gonna be slave labor. But your government should be obligated to make sure you are covered for healthcare. Not have access to healthcare, simply have healthcare

Especially in a country as wealthy as ours, Health Care should be a priority. There is no reason it is not Universal as in so many other countries in western Europe. Health care is a necessity to keep everyone "safe" and therefor it is a right and not a matter of privilege of who can pay! Yes, I agree with Bernie. Health care is a right.

This may piss you off, Brian, but the only "rights" you have are the ones allowed to you by the heavily armed military force that occupies the land you live in. "Natural Rights" as a concept is a myth that was a useful fiction to get people behind the  ... See More
So true

We all have the right to the services of Law Enforcement,Fire Protection , The Entire Criminal and Civil Justice System, The Entire US Military for our protection. All of the US Road system and it's upkeep and every other service already provided to al ... See More
Incorrect. Life amongst born humans is a right. Healthcare is in direct support of sustaining life. Such as food water and shelter. All three are basic human rights.
Swedes will tell you that universal healthcare makes capitalism more efficient, and increases political support for flexible free markets.
It's like public education.  In fact, IIRC there is more hard evidence that healthcare improves market outcomes than education, but I'd have to look the studies up to be sure.
Not that we'd ever want to run our healthcare system the way we run our schools, but still.

Healthcare is as much a 'right' as is the right to a personal Lamborghini  :)  A right that infringes on the individual freedoms of others (i.e. coerced theft in the form of taxes) is not a right at all. A right to breathe air, on the other hand, doesn't cost anyone anything at all. I do support law enforcement, as they should exist to uphold the individual freedoms, and therefore the right to justice.

I don't think positive rights are going to be popular in ten or twenty years.  I think once the global Boomer generation really start to eat up the developed world's fiscal resources, the idea that one has a right to an economic resource is going to suffer all sorts of criticism.

You can make a case for universal healthcare without resorting to positive rights, e.g. people can start businesses much easier if they aren't on the hook for their employee's healthcare right off the bat.

When a person chooses to work in health care they choose to care for all who show up. It is government's job to assure that everyone can show up when in need. Health care providers deserve a good living wage commensurate with their education. Companies ... See More
The bigger issue here is, why is healthcare even a thing in the first place? Look at Amish communities, they don't have to pay for health insurance because they take care of each other.
Health insurance is for Democrats that have no personal accountability.

Brian Cullinan seriously? The Amish pay for eachother... out of a pot of money they  all contribute to... which is exactly what health insurance is. It's a group of people paying money to a large pot to take care of eachother. The only difference is there is no "company" involved... it's just the people. Which makes it exactly like... you guessed it.. universal healthcare

comments.content: We didn't need Harvard to spend millions of money on research to figure this out.  All we had to do was listen to our Grandma/Momma tell us do the chores or u will grow up to be a bum

This is absolutely.the truth, I raised 5 of them and there wasn't a one of them that couldn't cook, clean house, make clothes,.feed cows, run a tractor, combine, do any kind of farm work, or.house work, kept there school work, honor work. And all 3 girls and 2 boys have professional jobs. They tell me now there glad we made.them do chores because they now made good choices in life.
I am a special ed. teacher and I insist all of my students help clean up our classroom every day. It doesn't matter how big or small, they need to feel like they're a part of a family!
Helping out around the house at age-appropriate levels is not only good training, it helps children feel that they are valuable within the family.

I expect a big THANK YOU from  Bob Smithson   Zack Smithson   Joshua Smithson  and  Christy Smithson-Ross .   You all started out as soon as you could hold a rag.  HaHa.  WooooHoooo I did something right
Can't tell you how many times I've expressed this to parents in meetings.  They look at me like i have six heads..."She's only seven...". Uh plenty that a seven year old can do.

As a parents we are responsible for teaching our children how to care for themselves (and incidentally for others) that means by the age of 18 or so they should be able to independently run a house including shopping, cleaning, garden and with enough knowledge to understand how to budget and to tackle basic home repairs. If you send your children out into the world without these skills you have failed as a parent
Lazy is the devil's underpants !  And when see someone with a heavy load you make it lighter & this kindness will follow you all your days !

Just don't use chores as a punishment and don't make one child do more chores than the others making it seem as though it's a punishment. One child who refuses to do the chore correctly should not get a pass but should be taken in hand and taught how to do the chore right. The one doing all the chores may end up with a better work ethic but may also end up resenting her parent and siblings.

My grandsons are 2 & 4 and they put their dirty clothes in the laundry, wipe up their spills, sweep with their play brooms, windex some things, and bring the trash cans from the curb to the yard after trash collection. I am there every second and they  ... See More

The ability to do for oneself has to be taught from early on, and we begin with chores. My boys need to at least know how to keep house, do laundry, cook, go grocery shopping, take care of the yard and the car, pet care, and of course follow a budget. These things became very real for them when I became ill back on February 10th.
Learning competence, responsibility and the fact that it's not somebody else's job to take care of you and the household messes

4 girls, always had chores, got jobs straight out of college, all successful professionals.  It's not for the lazy parent - there is a lot of nagging and reminding and checking to see what's done - but it is worth it in the long run.
Both of my girls started way young, when we owned our Canadian fishing camp....and kept on going after that, as amazingly successful Women

I fully believe in it! description: Brian Cullinan I have to share this solution for hiccups. It's too important not to.  Breath out as hard as you can so there is no air in your lungs and hold it for about 10 seconds. Then breath in as deeply as you can and hold it for 10 second. Then breath in slightly more grasping to fill you lungs with even more air and hold. Breath in again without breathing out and try to fit as much air in your lungs as possible. This method has worked for at least 3 other people.  When you can't hold your breath anymore, continue breathing normally. Jessica Sims

My daughter turns 13 this year and my friends always ask me how I get her to do her chores without fighting each day. It's simple. We have a system where she gets paid per chore. Not a lot, mind you, but small amounts like $0.50 to do the dishes or $0. ... See More

How many people do you know who have a housekeeper, cook, and gardener?  Chances are REALLY HIGH that your kid will have to do chores as an adult!! Make them normal and fun.  Teach them to take pride in their work and that little things matter.  They will thank you for it later.
My daughter was just telling me when I have her do a big chore project she is sad doesn't want to do it but once she completes it she has a sense of accomplishment and feels good about herself ☺

Not one time in this advertisement did I see a single one of these children actually connect two pieces together. That tells me that the friction between the two pieces are way too high for a child of this age to be able to connect. It means that it's really going to be a parent's doing all of the work. The only cutscene that showed two pieces actually sliding together was done with a big old pair of man hands.
All i see are a thousand large pieces scattered all across my livingroom floor and we already have legos for that! More power to the parents that can handle that.
Large cardboard box, imagination, crayons. Just as good, much cheaper, will be less strain on the environment when my son is ready for me to throw it out. The money I save goes to his college fund.

I am imagining a cry fest because a.) Kid 1 uses a piece to hit kid 2. b.) Kid 1's finger gets stuck while putting the pieces together. c.) Both kids build a rocket ship, which they launch via the staircase.
Why don't we just do what we did when I was a kid? They let us build real things. With wood and nails, fabric and thread, yarn. We cooked real food. Went real places. It was great!

Not even kidding...I saw this while stopped at a red light and left it open on my fb so I could tag you on it when I got to work! Lol. We are such an in sync team. Xoxo. So....buy a bigger house so we can get these for our kids. Ok. I had a dream last night that a man knocked on our door and offered to buy our house for $749,999.
